{{more citations needed|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} '''Opposition to immigration''' exists in most states with [[immigration]], and has become a significant political issue in many countries. Immigration in the modern sense refers to movement of people from one state or territory to another state or territory where they are not [[citizenship|citizens]]. [[Illegal immigration]] is immigration in contravention of a state's [[immigration law]]s.<ref name="ejas.revues.org">{{cite web|last1=Kozak|first1=Krystof|title=Are Immigrants Disloyal? The Case of Mexicans in the U.S.|url=https://ejas.revues.org/7629|website=European Association for American Studies|publisher=European Association for American Studies|accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref>
In the United States, opponents of immigration typically focus on perceived adverse effects, such as economic costs (job competition and burdens on education and social services); negative environmental impact from accelerated population growth; increased crime rates, and in the long run, changes in traditional identities and values.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Marisa Abrajano|author2=Zoltan L. Hajnal|title=White Backlash: Immigration, Race, and American Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0IGSBQAAQBAJ|year=2015|publisher=Princeton University Press|pages=31–35|isbn=9781400866489}}</ref> In Spain, surveys show "in descending order, jobs, crime and housing" as the primary concerns for citizens opposed to immigration.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Ray Hall|author2=Paul White|title=Europe's Population|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JIWNAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA136|year=2005|publisher=Routledge|page=136|isbn=9781135369484}}</ref>
Opposition to immigration ranges from calls for various [[immigration reform]]s to proposals to completely restrict immigration to one's [[nation]]; these often also include measures to combat [[immigration]] of existing citizens.
== Anti-immigration arguments == {{Further|Criticism of multiculturalism}}
=== National identity === {{See also|Cultural identity|Identity politics|Nationalism|#Import of culture}} Some critics of immigration argue {{citation needed|date=November 2018}} that the presence of immigrants may distort the [[national identity]] of the native population. That means that the native population opposes immigration because they fear they may lose their sense of belonging to their own nation, as represented by distinctive traditions, culture, language and politics.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/american_english/national-identity|title = Definition of National Identity in English|date = |accessdate = |website = Oxford Dictionaries|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
National identity can be an important factor for social peace in cases where there are intra-national divides. For example, a 2015 study showed that the educational content of [[Suharto]]'s [[Indonesia]] emphasizing the national unity of Indonesia was an important cause of improved inter-ethnic and inter-religious relationships.<ref>{{cite web|ssrn=2607454|title=Social Spillovers of a School Building Program: Evidence on Improved Inter-Ethnic and Inter-Religious Relationships|first1=Christopher|last1=Roth|first2=Sudarno|last2=Sumarto|date=2 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Isolation, separation and stability === {{See also|Ethnic conflict|Community cohesion|Social order|Hybrid warfare#Russian involvement with Middle-Eastern refugees|#National identity}} Immigrants may isolate themselves in their own communities, forming self-organized communities, [[ghetto]]s or [[Parallel society|parallel societies]] where they live according to their own culture, rather than assimilating to the native culture with a reduced or minimal spatial, social and cultural contact with the majority society into which they have immigrated. Such ethnic enclaves can be the result of humans naturally liking to be around people like themselves.<ref name=nationsornot>{{cite web|title=End of nations: Is there an alternative to countries?|url=http://mpc-journal.org/blog/2016/11/09/end-of-nations-is-there-an-alternative-to-countries/|publisher=New Scientist|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> They might not learn the local language and might eventually undermine the national unity, as well as the [[cultural]] and [[religious]] unity of the native country.<ref>[http://www.bpb.de/publikationen/URZDVA Parallelgesellschaften?], ''Aus Politik und Zeitgeschichte'', No. 1–2 (2006)</ref> Research by Jennifer Neal of Michigan State University suggests that ethnic enclaves promote [[social cohesion]] at the cost of decreasing tolerance between groups and that their size, autonomy and proximity are factors.<ref name=nationsornot/> Some also suggest to devolve more power to local communities.<ref name=nationsornot/>
Immigration may adversely affect social<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sobel|first1=Andrew|title=Challenges of Globalization: Immigration, Social Welfare, Global Governance|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135216955|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q4CMAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA96|accessdate=10 May 2017|language=en|date=2009-09-10}}</ref> and political stability.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Immigration and political stability|url=https://www.oecd.org/dev/pgd/46923664.pdf|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref>
=== Increased competition === Economic arguments concentrate on competition for employment, and the higher burdens that some groups of immigrants may impose on [[Social welfare provision|social welfare]] systems, health systems, housing and public schools of the native state.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/09/is-britain-full-home-truths-about-population-panic|title=Is Britain full? Home truths about the population panic|first=Andy|last=Beckett|date=9 February 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> For example, Denmark's strict immigration law reform has saved the country 6.7 billion euros compared to previous more permissive approach, according to a 2011 report from the Danish Integration Ministry.<ref name="spiegel">{{cite web | last = Reimann | first = Anna | title = Putting a price on foreigners: strict immigration laws 'Save Denmark Billions'|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/putting-a-price-on-foreigners-strict-immigration-laws-save-denmark-billions-a-759716.html |website =spiegel.de | publisher = Spiegel Online | date = 29 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref><ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |title=Denmark's immigration laws save country £6 billion|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/denmark/8492822/Denmarks-immigration-laws-save-country-6-billion.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | publisher = [[Telegraph Media Group]] |accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
=== Environmental space, quality and resource scarcity === The following are more an argument against [[Human overpopulation|overpopulation]] than against immigration, but sometimes overpopulation is caused by immigration. Some people think there is a certain size of land needed to provide for a population ("environmental space"), e.g., to provide for the population's consumption, including absorption of waste products.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.populationmatters.org/wp-content/uploads/population_problem_uk.pdf|title=The UK's population problem|publisher=}}</ref> Immigrants, in this logic, such as a new born child, reduce the per capita size of land of the native country. This idea dates back to [[Thomas Robert Malthus|Robert Malthus]] who claimed this in a similar way in the early 19th century.
Some are concerned about urban sprawl and congestion, alterations in the wildlife and natural environment of the state, and an expansive carbon footprint due to immigration.<ref name="scarce">{{cite journal|last1=Rohe|first1=John F|title=Living Standards, Scarce Resources and Immigration: An Interview With Labor Economist Vernon M. Briggs, Jr.|date=1 January 2006|url=http://digitalcommons.ilr.cornell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1205&context=articles|accessdate=28 January 2017|language=en}}</ref> Furthermore, some are concerned over a state's scarce resources, dwindling water reserves, energy, pauperized soils and solid waste.<ref name="scarce"/>
=== Diseases === Immigrants (and cross-border movements in general) can bring infectious diseases uncommon to the native population from their home countries<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dhooper|first1=Surjit Singh|title=Social Work in Health Care: Its Past and Future|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=9781483342573|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7dggAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA110|accessdate=12 February 2017|language=en|date=2011-11-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Diane|last2=Edwards|first2=Helen|last3=Seaton|first3=Lesley|last4=Buckley|first4=Thomas|title=Lewis's Medical-Surgical Nursing: Assessment and Management of Clinical Problems|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9780729582209|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G5u9BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA42|accessdate=12 February 2017|language=en|date=2015-01-29}}</ref><ref name="ep1"/><ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. – Mexico Cross-Border Health|publisher=Gateway to Health Communication {{!}} CDC|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthcommunication/toolstemplates/entertainmented/tips/us-mexico-health.html|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=12 February 2017|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gushulak|first1=B. D.|last2=MacPherson|first2=D. W.|title=Globalization of Infectious Diseases: The Impact of Migration|journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases|date=15 June 2004|volume=38|issue=12|pages=1742–1748|doi=10.1086/421268|url=https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/38/12/1742/304890/Globalization-of-Infectious-Diseases-The-Impact-of|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilder-Smith|first1=Annelies|last2=Shaw|first2=Marc|last3=Schwartz|first3=Eli|title=Travel Medicine: Tales Behind the Science|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136352157|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=821u8pqWgq4C&pg=PA218|accessdate=12 February 2017|language=en|date=2007-06-07}}</ref> which some perceive as a threat of significance in opposition to immigration.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lirola|first1=Maria Martinez|title=Discourses on Immigration in Times of Economic Crisis: A Critical Perspective|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=9781443865609|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z-UxBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA115|accessdate=12 February 2017|language=en|date=2014-08-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Polish opposition warns refugees could spread infectious diseases|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-migrants-poland-idUSKCN0S918B20151015|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=13 February 2017|date=15 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bruce|first1=Tammy|title=When foreigners bring disease across the border|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jan/25/tammy-bruce-when-foreigners-bring-disease-across-t/|publisher=The Washington Times|accessdate=13 February 2017}}</ref><ref name="The Guardian">{{cite web|title=The Mexican 'germ invasion' is just the right's latest anti-immigration myth|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jul/02/border-patrol-diseases-anti-immigration-myth|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=13 February 2017|date=2 July 2014}}</ref>
Some point out that this threat is often overstated by opponents.<ref name="The Guardian"/>
=== Immigrant crime === {{Main|Immigration and crime|}} Opponents of immigration often claim that immigrants contribute to higher crime rates, but research suggests that people tend to overestimate the relationship between immigration and criminality.<ref name=":37">{{Cite journal|last=Hooghe|first=Marc|last2=de Vroome|first2=Thomas|date=1 January 2016|title=The relation between ethnic diversity and fear of crime: An analysis of police records and survey data in Belgian communities |journal=International Journal of Intercultural Relations|volume=50|pages=66–75|doi=10.1016/j.ijintrel.2015.11.002}}</ref><ref name=":52">{{Cite journal|last=Nunziata|first=Luca|date=4 March 2015|title=Immigration and crime: evidence from victimization data |journal=Journal of Population Economics|volume=28|issue=3|pages=697–736|doi=10.1007/s00148-015-0543-2|issn=0933-1433}}</ref><ref name=":38">{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/markaz/2016/06/28/americas-puzzling-moral-ambivalence-about-middle-east-refugees/|title=America’s puzzling moral ambivalence about Middle East refugees|date=28 June 2016|newspaper=Brookings|language=en-US|access-date=26 January 2017}}</ref> The academic literature provides mixed findings for the relationship between immigration and crime worldwide, but finds for the United States that immigration either has no impact on the crime rate or that it reduces the crime rate.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Papadopoulos|first=Georgios|date=2 July 2014|title=Immigration status and property crime: an application of estimators for underreported outcomes|url=http://www.izajom.com/content/3/1/12/abstract|journal=IZA Journal of Migration|volume=3|issue=1|page=12|doi=10.1186/2193-9039-3-12|issn=2193-9039}}</ref><ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|last=Bianchi|first=Milo|last2=Buonanno|first2=Paolo|last3=Pinotti|first3=Paolo|date=1 December 2012|title=Do Immigrants Cause Crime? |journal=Journal of the European Economic Association|language=en|volume=10|issue=6|pages=1318–1347|doi=10.1111/j.1542-4774.2012.01085.x|issn=1542-4774}}</ref><ref name=":52"/><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Jaitman|first=Laura|last2=Machin|first2=Stephen|date=25 October 2013|title=Crime and immigration: new evidence from England and Wales |journal=IZA Journal of Migration|volume=2|issue=1|pages=1–23|doi=10.1186/2193-9039-2-19|issn=2193-9039}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Brian|last2=Fasani|first2=Francesco|last3=Machin|first3=Stephen|date=10 October 2012|title=Crime and Immigration: Evidence from Large Immigrant Waves |journal=Review of Economics and Statistics|volume=95|issue=4|pages=1278–1290|doi=10.1162/REST_a_00337|issn=0034-6535}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Brian|last2=Machin|first2=Stephen|date=1 February 2013|title=Immigrant Enclaves and Crime |journal=Journal of Regional Science|volume=53|issue=1|pages=118–141|doi=10.1111/jors.12003|issn=1467-9787}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Wadsworth|first=Tim|date=1 June 2010|title=Is Immigration Responsible for the Crime Drop? An Assessment of the Influence of Immigration on Changes in Violent Crime Between 1990 and 2000 |journal=Social Science Quarterly|volume=91|issue=2|pages=531–553|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6237.2010.00706.x|issn=1540-6237}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Piopiunik|first=Marc|last2=Ruhose|first2=Jens|date=6 April 2015|title=Immigration, Regional Conditions, and Crime: Evidence from an Allocation Policy in Germany|ssrn=2589824}}</ref><ref name=":362">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WtYEoD4u9RYC|title=Immigration, Crime and Justice|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|year=2009|pages=3–16|chapter=Immigration reduces crime: an emerging scholarly consensus|author1=Lee, Matthew T.|author2=Martinez Jr., Ramiro|isbn=9781848554382}}</ref><ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Brian|last2=Oxford|first2=University of|last3=UK|title=Crime and immigration|url=http://wol.iza.org/articles/crime-and-immigration|journal=IZA World of Labor|doi=10.15185/izawol.33|year=2014}}</ref>
=== Military unity === {{See also|Unit cohesion}} Some concerns regarding immigration can be found in perceived military loyalty, especially if the country of emigration becomes involved in a war with the country of immigration.<ref name="ejas.revues.org"/> Particularly if a country finds itself in the need of drafting.
=== Dangerous journeys === Many people make dangerous migration journeys<ref>{{cite web|title=Dangerous journeys – International migration increasingly unsafe in 2016|url=https://publications.iom.int/system/files/gmdac_data_briefing_series_issue4.pdf|accessdate=26 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Grant|first1=Martin Chulov Harriet|title=EU must open doors to avoid Syrian refugee catastrophe, says UN|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/13/syrian-refugee-catastrophe-european-union-united-nations|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=26 January 2017|date=13 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Perspectives on Global Development 2017 International Migration in a Shifting World: International Migration in a Shifting World|publisher=OECD Publishing|isbn=9789264265684|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cxG0DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA176|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2016-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Refugee Crisis and Europe|url=https://rusi.org/event/refugee-crisis-europe|publisher=RUSI|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Danger every step of the way|url=https://www.unicef.org/emergencies/childrenonthemove/files/Child_Alert_Final_PDF.pdf|publisher=UNICEF|accessdate=26 January 2017}}</ref> on which many have died.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australia asylum: Why is it controversial?|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-28189608|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=26 January 2017|date=3 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Anti-immigration mood weighs on EU politicians|url=https://www.ft.com/content/f4072b00-e8ff-11e4-b7e8-00144feab7de|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=26 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Office|first1=The Stationery|title=HL 46 – EU Action Plan against migrant smuggling|publisher=The Stationery Office|isbn=9780108558207|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NHBNCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA5|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2015-11-03}}</ref> Harshly restricting immigration and making these restrictions known to potential emigrants may prevent them from taking such dangerous journeys.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Farrell|first1=Paul|title=Could Australia's 'stop the boats' policy solve Europe's migrant crisis?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/22/could-australia-stop-the-boats-policy-solve-europe-migrant-crisis|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=26 January 2017|date=22 April 2015}}</ref>{{Better source|date=January 2017}}
=== Import of culture === {{Further|Islamization|Cultural conflict|#National identity}} Immigrants bring their culture with them.<ref>{{cite web|title=The gifts of immigration|url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2011/04/the-gifts-of-immigration/|publisher=Harvard Gazette|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Swain|first1=Laksha P.|title=Migration and Adjustment|publisher=Northern Book Centre|isbn=9788172112110|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U7nOhJszK3QC&pg=PA45|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|year=2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Flores|first1=Juan|last2=Flores|first2=Prof of Social and Cultural Analysis Juan|title=The Diaspora Strikes Back: Caribeño Tales of Learning and Turning|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135927592|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OVSTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PR7|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2010-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Chuang|first1=Susan S.|title=Immigrant Children: Change, Adaptation, and Cultural Transformation|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=9780739167069|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AeDXAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA239|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2011-06-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Muslims in France: Identifying a Discriminatory Equilibrium|url=http://ftp.iza.org/dp6953.pdf|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Rozell|first1=Mark J.|last2=Jelen|first2=Ted G.|title=American Political Culture: An Encyclopedia [3 volumes]: An Encyclopedia|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781610693783|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MuVjCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA953|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2015-04-28}}</ref><ref name="ep1">{{cite book|title=Epidemiology for Public Health Practice|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Publishers|isbn=9781449666637|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TLNMPc-Pa5oC&pg=PA168|accessdate=10 May 2017|language=en|date=2009-05-18}}</ref> The immigrants' thinking, their norms, practices, customs and values shape, extend and influence the native country's culture ([[Leitkultur]]). Some such extensions and influences might not be desired by parts of the native population, for reasons that may include practises considered less civilized, restrictions as well as collisions with the native country's norms, laws and values in general.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chapman|first1=Roger|last2=Ciment|first2=James|title=Culture Wars: An Encyclopedia of Issues, Viewpoints and Voices|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317473510|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XO9nBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA330|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2015-03-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Rahim|first1=Abdur|title=Canadian Immigration and South Asian Immigrants|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=9781499058727|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o22mBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT168|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2014-09-19}}</ref>{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}<ref>{{cite book|last1=Congress|first1=Elaine P. |last2=Gonzalez|first2=Manny J. |title=Multicultural Perspectives in Working with Families: Second Edition|publisher=Springer Publishing Company|isbn=9780826131461|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eujRZg308isC&pg=PA382|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2005-04-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Nyangweso|first1=Mary|title=Female Genital Cutting in Industrialized Countries: Mutilation or Cultural Tradition?|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781440833472|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9AyqBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA4|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|date=2014-10-20}}</ref>
=== Welfare costs === {{See also|Economic results of migration}} Opponents of immigration often state that immigrants have a net negative effect on public coffers mainly due to the provisioning of medical care and [[welfare]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Immigration and the Welfare State|journal=Cato Journal|url=https://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/serials/files/cato-journal/2012/1/cj32n1-11.pdf|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Cost of Welfare Use By Immigrant and Native Households|url=http://cis.org/Cost-Welfare-Immigrant-Native-Households|publisher=Center for Immigration Studies|accessdate=12 February 2017|language=en|date=6 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sowell|first1=Thomas|title=Applied Economics: Thinking Beyond Stage One|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=0786722703|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gh4JdTv-t9sC&pg=PT173|accessdate=25 January 2017|language=en|date=2008-12-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Bommes|first1=Michael|last2=Geddes|first2=Andrew|title=Immigration and Welfare: Challenging the Borders of the Welfare State|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134593705|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tQuEXKGPqfEC&pg=PA9|accessdate=25 January 2017|language=en|date=2003-09-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Report: More than half of immigrants on welfare|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/09/01/immigrant-welfare-use-report/71517072/|publisher=USA TODAY|accessdate=25 January 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Germany Announces Crackdown on Immigrant 'Welfare Abuse' {{!}} VICE News|url=https://news.vice.com/article/germany-announces-crackdown-on-immigrant-welfare-abuse|publisher=VICE News|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Welfare Use of Immigrants and Natives in Germany: The Case of Turkish Immigrants|url=http://www.laser.uni-erlangen.de/papers/paper/117.pdf|accessdate=25 January 2017}}</ref>
Various factors influence the impact of immigrants to a nation's public coffers and their use of welfare. While immigrants can improve a state's welfare system by for example counteracting trends of [[Population ageing|aging populations]] their net economic impact might also be negative.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Impact of Immigration on Germany’s Society|url=https://www.bamf.de/SharedDocs/Anlagen/EN/Publikationen/Forschungsberichte/fb01-einfluss-zuwanderung.pdf?__blob=publicationFile|publisher=Federal Office for Migration and Refugees|accessdate=12 February 2017|date=2005}}</ref><ref name=swed1>{{cite journal|title=Refugee immigration and public finances in Sweden|url=https://gupea.ub.gu.se/bitstream/2077/38323/1/gupea_2077_38323_1.pdf|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> [[George Borjas]], economics professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, states that "the more unskilled the immigrant, the more likely the immigrant will be a fiscal burden".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Horn|first1=Heather|title=The Economics—and Morality—of Admitting Refugees|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/02/welfare-state-refugees-europe/463272/|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref> High-skilled immigrants have better labor market prospects than those admitted based on kinship ties or for humanitarian reasons.<ref name=skill>{{cite web|title=Skill-based immigration, economic integration, and economic performance|url=https://wol.iza.org/uploads/articles/41/pdfs/skill-based-immigration-economic-integration-and-economic-performance.pdf|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> It also depends on the tenures, wages and ages of the immigrants<ref>{{cite web|title=Economic Impacts of Immigration: A Survey|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.360.324&rep=rep1&type=pdf|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> and the country's integration system.<ref name=skill/>
=== Damage to migrants' home countries === {{See also|Distance education|Knowledge transfer|Local hiring|Telecommuting|Periphery countries|National innovation system}} Some opponents of immigration argue that emigration of highly skilled or well-educated individuals may hurt their home countries – which could otherwise benefit from them and build up their economy and improve their social and political system (i.e. [[brain drain]]). However, the notion of a "brain drain" remains largely unsupported in the academic literature. According to economist [[Michael Clemens]], it has not been shown that restrictions on high-skill emigration reduce shortages in the countries of origin.<ref name="Clemens">{{Cite journal|last=Clemens|first=Michael|last2=Development|first2=Center for Global|last3=USA|title=Smart policy toward high-skill emigrants|url=http://wol.iza.org/articles/smart-policy-toward-high-skill-emigrants|journal=IZA World of Labor|doi=10.15185/izawol.203|year=2015}}</ref> According to development economist Justin Sandefur, "there is no study out there... showing any empirical evidence that migration restrictions have contributed to development."<ref name="oxfamblogs.org">{{Cite web|url=http://oxfamblogs.org/fp2p/migration-and-development-who-bears-the-burden-of-proof-justin-sandefur-replies-to-paul-collier-2/|title=Migration and Development: Who Bears the Burden of Proof? Justin Sandefur replies to Paul Collier {{!}} From Poverty to Power|website=oxfamblogs.org|access-date=3 July 2016}}</ref> Hein de Haas, Professor of Sociology at the University of Amsterdam, describes the brain drain as a "myth".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/eight-myths-about-migration-and-refugees-explained-a-1138053.html|title=Myths of Migration: Much of What We Think We Know Is Wrong|last=|first=|website=Spiegel Online|access-date=23 March 2017}}</ref> Research suggests that emigration (both low-and high-skilled) is beneficial both to the sending countries in terms of economy,<ref name=":72">{{Cite journal|last=di Giovanni|first=Julian|last2=Levchenko|first2=Andrei A.|last3=Ortega|first3=Francesc|date=1 February 2015|title=A Global View of Cross-Border Migration |journal=Journal of the European Economic Association|volume=13|issue=1|pages=168–202|doi=10.1111/jeea.12110|issn=1542-4774}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andreas|first=Willenbockel, Dirk|last2=Sia|first2=Go, Delfin|last3=Amer|first3=Ahmed, S.|date=11 April 2016|title=Global migration revisited : short-term pains, long-term gains, and the potential of south-south migration|url=http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/2016/04/26208170/global-migration-revisited-short-term-pains-long-term-gains-potential-south-south-migration|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cream-migration.org/publ_uploads/CDP_24_16.pdf|title=The Gain from the Drain – Skill-biased Migration and Global Welfare|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.voxeu.org/article/cross-border-movement-persons-stimulates-trade|title=Cross-border movement of globalization: what’s in it for developing countries? |journal=International Journal of Manpower|volume=37|issue=7|pages=1209–1226|doi=10.1108/IJM-08-2015-0116|issn=0143-7720}}</ref> |journal=The Economic Journal|language=en|volume=118|issue=528|pages=631–652|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0297.2008.02135.x|issn=1468-0297}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dinkelman |first=Taryn |last2=Mariotti
